title-group.article-title: Association between the triglyceride–glucose index and spine fracture: A cross-sectional study of American adults

contrib-group.aff: bXinjiang Medical University, Urumchi, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, China
cDepartment of Orthopaedics, Xi’an Central Hospital, Xi’an, Shaanxi, China.

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence: Ke Zhang, Department of Orthopaedics, Xi’an Central Hospital, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710000, China (e-mail: zhangke_medical@163.com).

The work cannot be used commercially without permission from the journal.

abstract.p: It is yet unknown how spine fracture in adults relate to the triglyceride–glucose (TyG) index. This study investigated the link between TyG index and spine fracture in the adult population of the United States by analyzing information derived from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey. Ultimately, this study comprised 10,187 participants was drawn from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (2005–2010, 2013–2014, and 2017–2020). The Participants were divided into quartiles by the TyG index, and correlations between the TyG index and spine fracture were found using subgroup statistical analysis, restricted cubic spline curves, receiver operating characteristic analysis, and weighted multiple regression. Eventually, we carried 10,187 individuals, of whom 211 (2.1%) had an incident spine fracture. The results of the adjusted multivariate logistic regression analysis shows that the TyG index increased the morbidity of spine fracture (odds ratios: 1.63, 95% confidence intervals: 1.15–2.30, P = .01) and the outcome of the stratified and sensitivity analyses remained stable and indicative of a nonlinear relationship. The findings of our study indicate that an elevated TyG index is associated with an increased susceptibility to spine fracture and demonstrates a moderate level of predictive capability.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Spine fracture is a serious public health issue, and its morbidity is rising rapidly on a worldwide scale.[1–3] Spine fracture is primarily osteoporosis vertebral compression fractures, in which the incidence increases significantly with age,[4] assessing the number of vertebral fractures in the US population at 5.2 million people by 2020, with the overall prevalence increasing from 2.2% to 4.6%. Global population aging is projected to increase further by 2050, accompanied by more fragility fractures.[5,6] Moreover, spine fracture causes serious financial and psychological burdens for patients and their families.[7,8] Therefore, given the demographic changes, it is important to assess the population early and take measures to reduce the incidence of spine fracture.

Insulin resistance, which is a common pathologic mechanism for the development of many disorders connected to metabolism, is defined as the body’s reduced capacity to utilize insulin for its physiological purposes. Besides, among people with type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, cardiovascular disease, and other diseases are frequently diagnosed with insulin resistance.[9,10] Based on conventional study finds diabetes and insulin resistance associated with skeletal and muscular systems.[11–13] A new index for detecting diabetes, is the triglyceride–glucose index. Previous researches have revealed that the triglyceride–glucose (TyG) index is related with disease prediction, cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, and other disorders.[14,15] Therefore, it is essential to explore the ease of fracture development by the index; The explicit relationship between the TyG index and spine fracture in US adults is not clear, although there are many researches on the subject. Our study was designed to examine the link between adult spine fracture in the US and the TyG index.

sec.title: 2. Materials and methods
sec.p: The National Center for Health Statistics conducts the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) to collect comprehensive health and nutrition statistics on the population of the United States. The minimum MEC sample weights were selected in order to acquire a representative sample of participants prior to the launch of the NHANES program to minimize the possibility of weighting errors caused by oversampling of the population. In addition, the sampling methods used in this study included stratified sampling, multistage sampling, and clustered probability sampling designs.[16,17]

In this study, we investigated information from all participants from NHANES (2005–2010, 2013–2014, and 2017–2020) (N = 66023) regarding data. More details on the research design, inclusion and exclusion criterion are presented in Figure 1. Based on previous studies,[18–20] we used other factors that may be confused with the TyG index: sex, age, ethnicity, education level, fasting blood glucose (FBG), fasting triglycerides, and insulin resistance. Through a standardized questionnaire. Smoking status was categorized into yes (smokers) (including current/former smokers) and no (never smokers); alcohol user was determined defining yes (an alcohol user) as someone who consumed more than 5 drinks per year; those who did not meet this criterion were classified as no (nondrinkers). Body mass index was grouped into 3 groups: emaciation (0–17.99), normal (18–24.99), overweight (25.0–29.9), and obese (30.0+); Diabetes, Stroke and Coronary Heart Disease (doctor has told you that you have these disease); The TyG index is a composite index composed of fasting glucose and fasting triglycerides with the specific formula: TyG = Ln [fasting triglycerides (mg/dL) × fasting glucose (mg/dL)/2]; Self-reported personal interview data included diagnostic information on spine fracture (participants were asked if they had ever been told by a doctor or expert that they suffered spine fracture). If “yes,” they were defined as patients with spine fracture. Previous studies have demonstrated the authenticity and feasibility of the self-reported spine fracture question.[4,21,22]

sec.title: 2.1. Statistical analysis
sec.p: The weighted mean (standard error) for continuous variables and the weighted mean percentage for categorical variables were used to represent the results of the study, all data are weighted, depending on the categories of values and distributional properties of the final included factors. The connection between the TyG index and spine fracture was analyzed using a multivariate weighted logistic regression model, and the odds ratios (ORs) and corresponding 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were computed. These covariates used in our research were selected on the basis of their relationship with the TyG index or the association with spine fracture. The multivariate logistic regression analysis models use 3 models: Model 1: unadjusted model; Model 2 adjusted for: age (years), ethnicity, sex, and education level; Model 3 adjusted for the following factors: age (years), ethnicity, sex, education level, body mass index status, alcohol user, smoke status, stroke, coronary heart disease, diabetes, relevant possible laboratory data include high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol. The research used fully adjusted model 2 for stratified analyses, weighted analyses, log-likelihood ratio tests, and sensitivity analyses were used to calculate interactive effects of subgroup variables by the TyG index and spine fracture. So as to investigate the linear relationship with spine fracture, we used restricted cubic spline curves to study the TyG index and spine fracture. In order to further investigate the efficacy of the TyG index in predicting spinal fractures, we selected a total of 4 indicators that were predictive of insulin resistance and determined the most suitable predictor by comparing the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve. For more information on complex data and design of sampling in NHANES, the specific websites are as follows: https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/index.htm. For all statistical analyses in this research, R version 4.3.0 (https://www.r-project.org/) was used. A P-value of <.05 is considered as calculating the data studied in this study as a measure of statistical significance.

sec.title: 3.1. The baseline study participant characteristics determined by the TyG index
sec.p: Figure 1 describes the full process of this design with 55,836 participants excluded. In order to explore spine fracture in this type of cross-sectional study, we relaxed the age limit (≥20 years old), and in the spine fracture case group, the average age was: 58.38 years, the youngest participant age was 20 years old, and only 27.58% of the age group was <50 years old. The final sample for this research included 10,187 NHANES participants of whom 49.80% were female, 46.20% were non-Hispanic white, and 211 (2.1%) suffered from spine fracture. The average value of the TyG index is 8.58 (8.19, 9.01). Table 1 shows the baseline study participant characteristics determined by the TyG index. Compared with the lower quartile, participants in the upper quartile were more possibly to be male and older, have a higher percentage of race being White and Mexican American and a much higher incidence in spine fracture. For all participants in this study, by one-way analysis of variance with TyG index, it was observed that age and the TyG index were positively associated (all P < .001), besides there was a negative link (all P < .001) between high-density lipoprotein cholesterol and the TyG index. After adjusting for all confounding variables, our study results show a 0.66-fold increase in spine fracture incidence for each unit increase in the TyG index (adjusted model 3: OR: 1.66, 95% CI: 1.16–2.38, P = .01).

fn.p: Significance was determined for P values below 0.05 (*), 0.01 (**), and 0.001 (***).

BMI = body mass index, FBG = fasting blood glucose, HDL = high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, LDL = low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, PIR = income-to-poverty ratio, TyG = triglyceride–glucose index.

sec.title: 3.2. Association between the TyG index and spine fracture
sec.p: The research of the multivariate regression analysis of the TyG index and spine fracture are demonstrated in Table 2. To further validate the association between an elevated TyG index and increased risk of spine fracture, we performed a weighted logistic regression analysis following quartile stratification of the TyG index. Compared to the first quartile, the TyG index of the fourth quartile significantly increases the risk of spine fracture (OR: 2.41, 95% CI: 1.21–4.79, P = .01, P for trend = .016). Subgroup analyses were employed to assess the connection between the TyG index and spine fracture after adjusting for Model 2. For the subgroup analyses, as Table 3 illustrates, after adjusting for variables other than the subgroup factors themselves, we were unable to find statistically significant differences in interactions. The nonlinear relationship between the TyG index and risk of spine fracture was better demonstrated when all-variable smoothed curve fitting was considered. The restricted cubic sample entries test as shown that the TyG index and spine fracture are shown in Figure 2, what can be seen that the correlation with spine fracture is higher before the TyG inflection point of 8.61 (P for overall < .001, P for nonlinear < .001), and diminishes after the inflection point. To further investigate the predictive efficacy of the TyG index for spinal fracture occurrence, we selected metabolic score for insulin resistance and FBG as additional groups to evaluate insulin resistance and subsequently predict the likelihood of spinal fractures.[23–26] According to Figure 3, the areas under the curve can be divided into TyG: 0.5852, MET-IR: 0.5303, and FBG: 0.5474, indicating that the TyG index exhibits superior efficacy in predicting spinal fractures with appropriate predictive ability.

caption.p: Association between the TyG index and spine fracture.

fn.p: Model 2: adjusted for age, sex, and ethnicity.
Model 3: adjusted for age, sex, ethnicity, education level, BMI, alcohol user, diabetes, HDL and LDL, smoke status, coronary heart disease, and stroke.
Model 3 was adjusted for all covariates except effect modifier.
95% CI = 95% confidence interval, OR = odds ratio.

caption.p: Relationship between the TyG and spine fracture. TyG = triglyceride–glucose index.
ROC analysis using 3 indexes for assessing insulin resistance to predict spine fracture. ROC = receiver operating characteristic.

sec.title: 4. Discussion
sec.p: Our outcome demonstrates that there was a statistically significant rise in the probability of spine fracture with increasing in the TyG index. Shieh et al performed a cross-sectional analysis of premenopausal and perimenopausal women and found an association between preexisting diabetes mellitus, insulin resistance, and lower trabecular bone scores. This finding raises the possibility of a relationship between women’s insulin resistance, diabetes mellitus, and women’s Musculo skeletal health.[27]

To further investigate the potential link to the skeletal system, Shieh observed a strong association between glycemic changes and fractures in a recent cohort study.[26] A cross-sectional research noticed that the risk of fragility fracture increases with fasting blood glucose and glycated hemoglobin concentrations. Besides, this research shows that elevated glycosylated hemoglobin and fasting glucose are reasons for fragility fractures, and the genetic link between these two variables was confirmed by a Mendelian randomization study.[28] To evaluate the relationship between various lipids and fracture, a study investigates the relationship between prevalence bone fractures and various lipid measurements, such as triglycerides by using Cox proportional hazard analysis on a sizable sample of people 50 years of age and older.[29] Chen et al (2019) evaluated the causal effects of various lipids, including triglycerides, on fracture risk through Mendelian randomization.[30] According to Broz et al, individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus that is terminally ill, accumulation of terminal products of late glycosylation contributes to musculoskeletal problems by altering the extracellular matrix, compromising cellular homeostasis, and activating the inflammatory cascade through its receptors, which leads to altered spine morphology.[31] Traumatic causes are a contributor to spine fracture, which can result in spinal cord injury. The study by Cheng et al found that the effect of spinal cord injury on glucose uptake and insulin resistance affected neurological and metabolic factors in bone health.[32] Additional, it has been noticed that aberrant neuronal activity upon spinal cord injury causes an excessive amount of triglycerides to be broken down, which raises the levels of triglycerides in patients.[33]

Research indicates a strong relationship between menopausal women’s lumbar spine bone density and insulin resistance.[34] A trial in diabetic patients observed a close link between vertebral fractures and insulin resistance, emphasizing that the reduction of insulin resistance may have potential advantages.[35] A correlation between baseline risk variables, such as triglyceride levels, and the prevention of vertebral fractures have been discovered.[36] Given its simplicity, the TyG index is frequently used as a diabetic monitoring tool. In a study with a 6-year follow-up, Jiangmei et al observed that in older diabetic women, higher levels of the TyG index was connected with spine fracture.[37] To investigate the link between insulin resistance and the musculoskeletal system in teenager individuals, Karimi et al found that there was a negative correlation between the relationship between insulin resistance and indicators of bone health, such as bone density, in young people by studying 423 participants.[38] Based on the above numerous studies, the role of insulin resistance in the skeletal muscular system can be expected, suggesting that the TyG index increases the risk associated with spine fracture, which is consistent with the results of our analysis. However, Zhangxin et al, in a prospective study of 832 nondiabetic patients, showed that TyG index was negatively correlated with fracture danger in nondiabetic middle-aged and elderly men, which is contrary to the results of our statistical analysis.[39] This emphasizes the necessity of further research to clarify the specific mechanisms by which insulin resistance is pertaining to bone health effects. Across conclusion, the review of literatures suggests a complicated relationship among spine fracture, triglycerides and insulin resistance, which may have ramifications for bone health across various kinds of demographics. To further understand the underlying mechanisms and create tailored therapies to enhance the health of the skeleton in insulin-resistant patients, further research is required.

There is a tendency for the TyG index to be used in place of insulin resistance in the evaluation of patients with diabetes given its accessibility and convenience. As a result, we have tried to evaluate spine fracture using a novel predictor, the TyG index. Thus, we have attempted to utilize a new predictor, the TyG index, to assess spine fracture. The NHANES sample weights were used in our analysis for statistical analyses, and we used corrected covariates to minimize the effects of confounders, which would increase the reliability of our results and allowed for its use in large population analyses. Undeniably, our research has certain limitations and constraints. Spine fracture obtained using personal interview conversations with some return bias. Owing to limitations of the NHANES database, our sample size of cases was too small, which may have increased sample bias; however, after adjusting for confounders, we did not find statistically significant effects of age factors, gender, or ethnicity on the total effect in our stratified analyses. Also, in contrast to previous studies, the type of diabetes mellitus was not identified during the collection process in the NHANES database, which does not guarantee what type of diabetes mellitus affects the differences in fractures, and the cross-sectional type of study does not ensure a causality by the TyG index and spine fracture. To examine the relationship between the adult’s TyG index and a spine fracture, only spine fracture was considered as an outcome, ignoring the significant effect of osteoporosis on it. Characteristics of constrained and cross-sectional studies, the study’s conclusion—that a higher TyG index is related to much more spine fracture occurred—requires validation through randomized, double-blind, multicenter, prospective longitudinal cohort researches.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: Our statistical results show that the TyG index is closely related with spine fracture in adults. Every 1.0 unit increase in the TyG index level is related with a 0.66-unit increase in spine fracture rate, and smoke increases the risk of spine fracture. After adjusting for confounders and subgroup analyses, our results remain stable. The TyG index, a simple index, can therefore be attempted to evaluate the risk of spine fracture. However, further studies such as observational as well as prospective researches with larger case sample sizes are still needed to validate the effect of the TyG index on spine fracture.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: We are grateful to the National Center for Health Statistics staff at the Centers for Disease Control for their efforts in organizing, developing, and collecting the NHANES data and creating an open database.
